title: PACOM Hijackings between 2009 and 2011(Completed) GEO
name: PACOM Hijackings between 2009 and 2011(Completed) GEO
description: This data and map presents hijackings committed by the Communist Party of India-Maoist group between 2009 and 2011.

properties.event summary: 04/14/2009: On Tuesday, Communist Party of India- Maoist Nexals hijacked a campaign vehicle for a JD(U) candidate and fled with the driver in Karma-Vishnupur village in Aurangabad, Bihar, India. No Casualties were reported.
properties.event title: CPI-Maoist Nexals Hijack Vehicle in Aurangabad

properties.event summary: 04/22/2009: On Wednesday, around 200 Communist Party of India- Maoist militants hijacked the Gomo-Mughalsarai train (number 627) carrying nearly 700 passengers near the Hehegarha station in Latehar, Jharkhand, India. The militants released the train at 1150. no casualties were reported.

10/27/2009: On Tuesday, at about 1425 hrs, left-wing extremists seized the 2443 New Delhi-bound Bhubaneswar Rajdhani Express train and held 1, 200 passengers hostage in West Bengal, India. According to sources, 300 Maoists and Maoist supporters waiving red flags blocked the tracks and stopped the New Delhi-bound train between Jhargram and Sarna stations of the South Eastern Railway. Co-driver K. Govind Rao said he was forced to stop the train by applying the emergency brakes when a group of men, who stood on the track, waved a red flag. As soon as the train stopped, the group asked the passengers as well as the drivers to get down and switch off their mobiles. He, however, added that none of them was manhandled.  Driver K Ananth Rao and his assistant K G Rao claimed that the rebels climbed into the cabin and order them to disembark, they then took away cell phones and walkie-talkies form the drivers and railway guard BB Rao. They reported that some of the rebels started painting slogans demanding the release of Mahato, a rebel leader, on the compartments in red ink. The passengers were told to get off the train and sit on the platform. The rebels reportedly abducted the driver and assistant driver of the train, however, it was later clarified that they were only detained.  After nearly five hours of being held hostages, the passengers were released and the train was secured by the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) and state police. It was reported that  upon the arrival of the CRPF and state police that there was an exchange of fire between the rebels and the forces in which a police driver took a bullet in the arm. The rebels claimed that two passengers were killed when the police forces fired mortars at them. Police, however, refute the reports claiming there was no exchange of fire and that a civilian driver was injured by firing but there were no injuries to security personnel. Home minister P Chidambaram said the Centre has rushed a relief train to Orissa with doctors and relief supplies. Chidamabaram confirmed the drama ended five hours after the kidnapping. The train was reportedly detained by the Maoists to demand the release of a top rebel leader, Gandhy, who is in police custody after being arrested in New Delhi last month. Other reports suggested that the supporters of the Maoists, the PCPA, had demanded the release of their leader Chhatradhar Mahato. The reports on the Maoist supporters involved are sketchy, in which the Maoist-backed Police Santrash Birodhi Janasadharaner Committee (PSBJC)  and the armed cadres of People's Committee against Police Atrocities (PCPA) are indicated in the attack. The PCPA claimed responsibility for the attack stating that the train drivers had defied the bandh called to protest against alleged atrocities by security forces on villagers.
properties.event title: Train Seized By Rebel; 1, 200 Taken Hostage, West Bengal, India.

properties.event summary: 07/04/2009: On Saturday, in Magra, Gaya, Bihar, India, assailants hijacked three buses belonging to the Maharani Transport Company, kidnapping three bus drivers and three bus conductors.  Later, the assailants released the victims and set fire to the buses, damaging the three buses.  No group claimed responsibility, but authorities believed the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) was responsible.
properties.event title: Assailants Hijacked Three Buses in Gaya, Bihar, India

properties.event summary: 06/20/2009: On Saturday, in Beijingwada, Malkangiri District, Orissa, India, a bus was hijacked by suspected Communist Party of India-Maoist militants. The bus was released, along with its occupants, the following day.
properties.event title: CPI-M Militants Hijacked a Bus in Orissa, India

properties.event summary: 03/10/2010: On Wednesday, between Dhanora and Yerkad village in Gadchiroli, Maharashtra, India, Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres hijacked a truck which was transporting ammonium nitrate, raw material for manufacturing explosives. Nearly 16 metric tonnes of raw materials were stolen.
properties.event title: CPI-M Militants Hijacked Truck Carrying Explosives

properties.event summary: 07/23/2010: On Friday, in Mardadand village, Bijapur, Chhattisgarh, India, unidentified militants hijacked a bus belonging to a private travel company, Tomar Travels, after evacuating all 22 passengers. Reportedly, the rebels stopped the bus, searched the luggage of the passengers and then asked them to get down. The rebels also warned the people against travelling on buses driving on that route, saying the vehicles could get caught in landmine blasts. Security personnel later recovered the bus from State Highway 16. No casualties or damages were reported. The specific motive for the attack is unknown; however, police suspect the attack was carried out to extort money from the bus operators. No group claimed responsibility, but it was suspected that Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) militants were responsible.

05/17/2010: On Monday, in Bastar, Chhattisgarh, India, unidentified assailants hijacked one truck carrying high-grade ammonium nitrate. No group claimed responsibility, although it was believed a Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-M) faction was responsible.

06/30/2010: On Wednesday, in Munger, Bihar, India, assailants hijacked one vehicle prior to holding the driver hostage and then beheading him.  No group claimed responsibility, although it was widely believed a Maoist faction was responsible.
properties.event title: Suspected Maoists Hijack Vehicle Before Beheading Driver in Munger, Bihar, India
